resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
Nlte opened a new pull request #11040:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11040


   Following https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-13699
   Here are small improvement proposals for the python filesystem docs.
   
   The goal is to make it more explicit what filesystem comes natively with PyArrow and what falls under fsspec third party libraries.
   
   - Added sections for each native PyArrow filesystem
   - Extended the fsspec section with additional code examples
   


--

pitrou commented on a change in pull request #11040:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11040#discussion_r707541657



##########
File path: docs/source/python/filesystems.rst
##########
@@ -200,10 +240,34 @@ For example::
    import pyarrow.dataset as ds
    ds.dataset("data/", filesystem=fs)
 
+::
+
+   # Similarly for Azure Blob Storage
+   import adlfs
+   # ... load your credentials and configure the filesystem
+   fs = adlfs.AzureBlobFileSystem(account_name=account_name, account_key=account_key)
+
+   import pyarrow.dataset as ds
+   ds.dataset("data/", filesystem=fs)

Review comment:
       Nice! Did you check this actually works?




--

Review comment:

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
As a python developer working with different cloud vendors and their storages I'd like to quickly jump to code examples on how to read and write files for each filesystem.

The documentation concerned is the python/filesystem doc: [https://arrow.apache.org/docs/python/filesystems.html]

I find the information is a bit scattered and could be improved by having the following organisation.
h1. Filesystem Interface

_overview of the Pyarrow FS Interface_
h2. Usage
h3. Local Filesystem

_description_
h4. Writing files

_code example_
h4. Listing files

_code example_
h4. Reading files

_code example_
h3. S3 Filesystem

_description / configuration_
h4. Writing files

_code example_
h4. Listing files

_code example_
h4. Reading files

_code example_
h3. Hadoop Filesystem

_description / configuration_
h4. Writing files

_code example_
h4. Listing files

_code example_
h4. Reading files

_code example_
h3. Extending to fsspec-compatible filesystems

_description_
h4. Google Cloud Storage

_code example_
h4. Azure

_code example_

That way a developer working on s3 can directly jump to the section of interest and start experimenting with the code examples.
 Additionally if new python bindings are created for a "Arrow native" filesystem the documentation can be extended with a new section in same vein as the other.

comments.body:
I'll happily put up a PR for this refactor in the next few days / 1-2 weeks if the maintainers think it's a good idea. That will get me started with the contributing workflow of Arrow.

I have access to s3 and azure + i can probably spin up a HDFS cluster with docker to test the code examples.

I think that if code examples are what we are looking for, probably adding recipes to the cookbook is a better way to achieve it. The documentation should probably keep a more tutorial/explaination style, if you are just looking for code snippets to copy/paste the cookbook is usually the place for those.

[~Nlte] if you want to have a look at the cookbook the codebase is available at https://github.com/apache/arrow-cookbook and it's hosted on https://arrow.apache.org/cookbook

ok [~amol-] that makes sense to put the code recipes in the cookbook indeed. I'll see if I can add that and draft a PR in the arrow-cookbook repo.

I think this issue can be closed.

[~Nlte] those docs can certainly be improved, thanks for your interest in contributing to that!

My main worry is that we get quite some duplication of content if each filesystem-specific section will also explain how eg {{get_file_info}} works. But maybe you could do a PR with changes how you see it for one filesystem as a starter, and then we can discuss from there?

Sorry, ignore my comment ;) (consequence of having opened this in a tab this morning and the laggy JIRA interface not refreshing itself if there are new comments ...)

Personally, I think some improvements also belong in the main docs. For example mentioning Azure through fsspec could fit there as well?

Rereading the documentation, it's true the outline in the description would lead to unnecessary code duplication.

I'm going to experiment with azure this weekend / next week. I can creqte a PR at the same time with a bit about Pyarrow and Azure at the bottom like for GCFS for sure.

I think I have pinpointed what I found unclear with the current doc (arrow native / fsspec) and I've submitted a PR here [https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/11040] if someone wants to have a look. However the CI wants this ticket in progress and I can't find a way to self assign.
[~Nlte] you should be able to self-assign tickets from now on, I've updated the current ticket too (sorry for the noise around the assignee, I clicked the wrong button in JIRA)
